results.title: The Australian mallee
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Australian Wildlife”.
A study of the wildlife of the Victorian Mallee, a land of drifting sand and Mallee Scrub. Small animal life struggles for existence under these poor conditions, where rare waterholes mean life or death. The interesting Mallee Fowl which buries its eggs in incubating mounds, and mysteriously controls its heat; and the Bowerbird which builds a so-called bower for its mating display are shown, together with Wedgetailed eagles, kangaroos, ant lions, honeyeaters and Major Mitchell cockatoos. Photographed by Robert H. Clarke, narrated by Peter Wagner and devised by naturalist Graham Pizzey.

results.title: The Australian littering quest
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Film Corporation, Damien Parer and Jack Zalkalns
results.brief_description: A satirical look at the four contestants hopeful of winning Australia’s littering quest. Describes the various ways they do their littering - including leaving rubbish at a picnic, throwing out “throw-away litter bags”. The judge, a computer, comments on their achievements and announces the winner. Cast includes Tom Paine, Pauline David, Rod Bryer, Guy Doro-Sainter, Monika Tokarski, Ema Ganet.

results.title: The Australian impressionists 1888-1896
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye”.
A look at paintings by Australian impressionists - A Holiday at Mentone: Charles Conder (1888). The Breakaway: Tom Roberts (1890-91). Fire’s On, Lapstone Tunnel: Arthur Streeton (1891). Moonrise, Templestowe: David Davies (1894). On the Wallaby Track: Frederick McCubbin (1896).

results.title: The Australian image. Pt. 3
results.creator_credit: S. Issac, C Hunniford, Ray Edmondson and N. Hildyard
results.brief_description: A collection a four documentaries on the development of the Australian film and sound industries. The first part, entitled “Wonders of the Age”, presents internationally acclaimed Australian inventions such as race-camera, Imax giant screen projector and CMI computer music systems. The second part, entitled “Shed a Silent Tear”, looks at the making, as well as the restoration, of Australian silent films. The third part, entitled “The One Eyed Monster”, looks at the growth of Australian television industries, the production of series, mini-series, variety shows, news and sports coverage’s, and the ways in which television affected Australian life. The last part, entitled “A Future for the Past” shows how images of Australians are reflected in films, and efforts to preserve films and sound recordings by the National Film and Sound Archive.
results.creator_credit_for_label: S. Issac, C Hunniford, Ray Edmondson and N. Hildyard

results.title: The Australian image. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: N. Hildyard, Ray Edmondson and C Hunniford
results.brief_description: Stop Laughing This is Serious explores the comedy of our past. From “Dad ‘n’ Dave” to “Crocodile Dundee”, the distinct Australian humour is reviewed on film. “Hooray for the Radio” follows the development of the radio world through the unique Australian voice. “The Other Film Industry” explores the important role of the documentary in recording events and images as they were. “You gotta be kidding” is a delightful review of film and radio from a child’s eye. Watch for “Kid’s Stakes”, “Bush Christmas”, “Storm Boy” and others.

results.title: The Australian image. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: C Hunniford, Ray Edmondson and N. Hildyard
results.brief_description: Lost and Found explores the early moving images of Australia and their interdependence on our national identity. These ageing films and sound recordings can be preserved with the vital assistance of the National Film and Sound Archive. “Days When the World Was Young” looks at the representation of Australian landscape in film and it’s effect on early identity. “It’s On Record” provides a background for the history of sound recordings. “Hot from the Spot to the Screen” watch the early news events that shaped the nation captured in sound and on film.

results.title: The Australian Government System
results.creator_credit: Canberra. College of Advanced Education. Media Centre, Public Service Board and Ian Hart
results.brief_description: Provides a broad description of the Australian Government System. Addresses the legislative arm of government including the Governor General, the Senate and House of Representatives. Overviews the executive arm of Government including the Executive Council. Introduces Departments, Authorities and the Federal Judiciary including both the High Court and Family Court of Australia.
